distribution.text: Copyright Â© Red Hat, Inc. All rights reserved.

notes.text: An update for nss is now available for Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8.8 Extended Update Support and Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8.
notes.title: Topic

notes.text:
Network Security Services (NSS) is a set of libraries designed to support the cross-platform development of security-enabled client and server applications.

Bug Fix(es) and Enhancement(s):

* Rebase NSS to 3.101 for Firefox (JIRA:RHEL-46849)

* nss: Mozilla: Memory corruption in NSS (JIRA:RHEL-47119)

* nss: Mozilla: Memory corruption in NSS [rhel-8.10.z] (JIRA:RHEL-47120)

* In FIPS mode, NSS DH_NewKey() fails because RNG_RNGInit() was never called (JIRA:RHEL-5263)

* nss: PK11_Encrypt using CKM_CHACHA20 can reveal plaintext on Intel Sandy Bridge machines [rhel-8.10.z] (JIRA:RHEL-53576)
notes.title: Details

document.title: Red Hat Bug Fix Advisory: nss bug fix and enhancement update

cwe.name: Improper Restriction of Operations within the Bounds of a Memory Buffer

notes.text:
The Mozilla Foundation Security Advisory describes this flaw as:

A mismatch between allocator and deallocator could have lead to memory corruption.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text:
Red Hat Product Security rates the severity of this flaw as determined by the Mozilla Foundation Security Advisory.

Firefox and Thunderbird in Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8.8 and later are not affected by this vulnerability, as they use the system NSS library. Firefox and Thunderbird in earlier Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8 extended life streams were affected, and should be updated to fixed versions as they become available.
notes.title: Statement

notes.text: The CVSS score(s) listed for this vulnerability do not reflect the associated product's status, and are included for informational purposes to better understand the severity of this vulnerability.
notes.title: CVSS score applicability

remediations.details:
For details on how to apply this update, which includes the changes described in this advisory, refer to:

https://access.redhat.com/articles/11258
